body:
@dongjoon-hyun Thanks for the suggestion! I have two questions: 1) how did you find out 8GB?  2) Is this needed only for Mesos? I never experienced with YARN integration tests especially for Vortex.

At this moment, I'm running tests on Mesos after changing the memory as you suggested. I'll share the result once it's done.

The Vortex tests still are not passing. I suspect there are other problems because the amount of resources are not that huge in Vortex tests (2 Evaluators with 4 cores and 64MB). I'll take a loot at this issue tomorrow.

Oh, too bad. Sorry for that. See you tomorrow.
You had better go to sleep. (In South Korea, it's 4:30AM, isn't it?)
I've checked that `mvn site:site` places `doap.rdf` in `website\target\staging\site`, and that `update_website.py` updates the file in the new location correctly. I'll merge
Thank you for reviewing and merging, @tcNickolas .

I was testing Alias defined for evaluator configuration which are in Common and used by Tang deserialization **implicitly**. BTW, evaluator.config  was not able to be deserialized by Tang in old Evaluator before I made the change.

Basically those tests are to test the configuration in evaluator.config.  There are a few things covered in those tests:
- language setting in evaluator config is correctly set. That was newly introduced. I wanted to inspect it inside the config.
- alias, to make sure we are able to deserialize with alias. The deserialization itself uses the code modified in Tang to handle alias situation. Yes, we can have a unit testing in Tang. However here we want to make sure the alias classes created for Evaluator configuration is working. Those alias classes are defined for Evaluator not in Tang. You don’t see the classes are explicitly used in the test but they are called behind the deserialization process. They are used in class hierarchy and Configuration and the caller won’t see it. 
- I want to make sure service, context and task configuration passed over from driver are all deserializable. So that later, when we change Task, Context and service to properly use Tang, we won’t have any deserialization issue but refactor code only. 

For now, if anything is broken, we can simply replace the evaluator.config to see what caused issue. Later, we should auto generate evalutor.config when we get time. 

Actually even using hard code evaluator.config also helps us to test other portion. In many unit test code, we mock input data, that is equivalent. 

We can definitely clean up some of them if they are not useful in current situation.
@markusweimer ,  do you have additional comments?
@tcNickolas made the changes.
@jwang98052 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!

I've done a pass. The build works for me with this change.

One more question: do we want to have one `.targets` file for all common targets, and eventually include it to almost every project? Or do we want to create separate `.targets` files for different functional groups (for example, targets related to xUnit testing, targets related to version information etc.) and include only necessary groups to each project (for example, xUnit will be present only in ~9 test projects)? In the second case, it might make sense to rename current `build.targets` to something more specific (`version.targets`) with respect to future.

@tcNickolas I think the answer lies in the separation of ideal vs practical. My guess is whatever works for the team and whatever consistently builds. It is just important to avoid targets that touch shared resources. Unfortunately I do not have the foresight nor experience to comment what should be the future direction here.

My main concern lies with the addition of `Extensible*RuntimeConfiguration` classes which are `public`. That really shouldn't be needed, but I also don't see a graceful alternative. I will test this locally. Have you tested on HDI?

@afchung I took a look. LGTM except the minor comments.
Please test for both YarnREST and Yarn legacy clients.
@anupam128 I've addressed your comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
No, I didn't test on HDI. Don't we have CI tests running on real clusters? I did test locally (but together with my other change)
Not automatically, no. You have to copy the reef-tests jars to the cluster and use `runtests.ps1` to launch them.
HDI tests pass
Looks good, the build still works and tests pass. I'll merge
I have also run tests for both YARN clients on a YARN cluster. Thanks!
Sounds good! :)
Hi, @yunseong . Could you review and merge this PR, too? I think you're the best man to do that. :-)

Hi, @yunseong . 
Could you review this PR someday, too? :-)
Since our release is postponed, it's not an urgent issue.
I'll be self-merging this, provided that @anupam128 is a committer now but hasn't yet gotten write-permission to the Github repo. Thanks!

We don't have any unit test to test alias created for Evaluator for cross language configuration deserialization. Those tests are in particular for evaluator configuration and implicitly call classes we created for evaluator therefore cannot be tested in Tang. 
I have created REEF-1201 to revert the deletion.
Hi, @afchung . It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
Thanks for checking. I will merge.
Uh oh, now it no longer merges with `master`. @shulmanb can you please rebase and resolve conflicts?
Looks good. Just left a couple of minor comments.
@jwang98052 I've addressed your comments. Please have another look. Thanks!

Would it make sense to include a separate configuration which runs only Tests? I am not sure if it is a good idea to hamper the dev workflow of building and running selective tests during active development. Thoughts?

You can still build and test separate project and run separate test using Visual Studio or non-default command line (msbuild with /t flag or xunit.console.runner). The only thing that is restricted is running tests without building code before that, but that doesn't feel like a problem to me, since the code needs to be rebuilt anyways.
So, this makes it so that running `msbuild` always also runs tests? That could be inconvenient, as I frequently just want to compile without tests.

I have tested this PR, it looks good. 
Since we reverted the evaluator tests, what I suggest you to do is to merge from master, then 
either modify CanInjectAndExecuteTask as TaskConfiguration has been changed
or remove CanInjectAndExecuteTask test only, as you already created new tests in TaskRuntimeTests in this PR to test Task.
 I will then merge it.
Running "Build" in Visual Studio is running the tests and failing build. Am I doing something wrong?

It seems inconvenient for developers as most of the time during development, we build in VS but we don't want always run tests. 
Can we leave "build" only as default in csproj. For xUnit console runner, pass additional flag for it to run testing?
Looking at it now.
I'm looking into why passing targets to msbuild explicitly doesn't override default targets. From documentation it seems like it should, but if I try `/t:Build` it still runs tests also.
This looks good to me. I'll test and merge.
@jwang98052 I've rebased and fixed the test according to your suggestions. Thanks for the CR!
I completed a pass.

@jwang98052 Just a heads up, but I will need to rebase and force-push this branch due to the merge conflict. Without the rebase, it will result in you having a rebase conflict again upon merging into master. I will address your comments as well. Thanks!
@anupam128 Please have a look when you have time. Thanks!

This needs more experimentation, and I won't be able to finish till late next week. So I'll recall this PR and send a new one later. Want to make sure that 
1) all tests can be executed with 1 command
2) tests can run without build (for example, for catching transient errors)
3) build can run without tests
+1 for the above 3 point proposal
@afchung Sure will take a look.
Is this a breaking change for users? How is public API impacted in terms of the way users were specifying these values?
@anupam128 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!

@markusweimer can you please confirm that we can skip the deprecation phase here?
Rest of the code LGTM.
@jwang98052 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!
Was this API ever a part of a release? If not, all changes are fair game.
@markusweimer I believe it was part of last release.
In that case, we might have to do the deprecation route. Is it possible to offer both parameters, with the new one dominating if both are set?
@anupam128 @markusweimer I've reverted the behavior of `MaxApplicationSubmissions` to be backward compatible for the old REEF client and deprecated it. Thanks!
I've done a pass.
Merged with latest, Markus please merge
I will test and merge
@markusweimer I've addressed your comments. Please have another look when you have time. Thanks!
Yarn tests passed after merge
I will try to test and merge.
I'll merge
@shulmanb The current commit doesn't have the commit message anymore. I will copy the one from the beginning of the PR. OK?
@shulmanb Ah, nevermind. The commits are still there.
Opening another one for REEF-1206.
This looks good, will merge.
I've done a pass.
I completed the pass.
@jwang98052 @markusweimer I've further addressed your comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
@afchung So the `_injector` is in `TaskStatus` is only for the deprecated code paths?
@markusweimer Yes, initially it was only for the deprecated code baths, but I opted to have `ITaskStart` and `ITaskStop` directly injected at the end. Thanks!
@markusweimer Thanks for the review. I have addressed the review comments.

LGTM

@jwang98052 can we merge?
I will test and merge.
@anupam128 @beysims Please have a look when you have time. Thanks!
@gwsshs22 Could you provide a bit more background on what was causing the test to fail? Thanks!

Hi, @afchung. Thanks for your interest. @gwsshs22 provided a description on the JIRA comment (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1040?focusedCommentId=15151849&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15151849). It'd be great if you take a look. Thanks!
@yunseong I see, thanks!
@gwsshs22 I understand now. I've left some comments on the JIRA for further thought, but this looks good to me for the purposes of unblocking the release. Thanks!
Any more comments @markusweimer ?
This LGTM. This is an API deprecation so I would like @markusweimer / @jwang98052 / @beysims to take a look as well.
@shulmanb Do you use any of the affected APIs?
@markusweimer Please take a look on this one as well.
@markusweimer ASA uses their own client.
I'll merge this in another 24 hours if no one objects.
@markusweimer, if you don't have any more comments, I would like to let @tcNickolas to merge for me before the cut off of 0.14 in this weekend.
In that case, I have no issues with merging this.
@anupam128 could you merge please? Thanks!
I'll test and merge. We can revisit the arch discussion over on JIRA.
Yes. I will test and merge this change.
This looks good to me.
LGTM. Will test and merge.
+1 for merging this.
I'll test and merge this today.
I'll test and merge this as well. Thanks!
Oh, thank you!
Thanks again! :)

In addition, what would be the best policy to keep the release versions (in other words, discard old versions)? Wouldn't it be enough to have _at most_ 2 latest versions for each platform? Any thought?
